customer_addr:
4001 S W CANYON ROAD
PORTLAND, OR 97221

citations.narrative:
Areas of peeling and chipped paint were observed in two of the nonhuman primate enclosures. In room 3 of the Lemur
holding enclosures, the majority of the back wall of the enclosure had multiple areas of chipped paint resulting in exposure
of the porous concrete wall surface. In the Tree Top Guenon holding enclosure, multiple areas of peeling paint were
observed on the lower portion of the walls and on the floor exposing old paint and floor surfaces. Failure to maintain
surfaces of housing facilities hinders the ability to adequately clean and sanitize and may affect the health and well-being
of the animals. All surfaces must be maintained on a regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities that cannot be readily
cleaned and sanitized must be replaced when worn or soiled.
To be corrected by July 10, 2024.

On January 9, 2024, a 5-year-old male Maccoa duck was found deceased in the filtration skimmer of the pool in Vollum
Aviary. Subsequently, on January 17, 2024, the remaining ~6.5-year-old Maccoa duck and an 11-year-old female Ruddy
duck were found deceased in the skimmer of the pool in the same enclosure. Failure to provide structurally sound and
well-maintained enclosures can allow for the entrapment of animals and lead to possible injury or death. Primary
enclosures must be designed and constructed of suitable materials so that they are structurally sound. The primary
enclosures must be kept in good repair and protect the birds from injury.
Corrected prior to the inspection date, June 26, 2024.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, several large adult rats were observed scurrying about in the flamingo enclosure. Facility
personnel indicated they knew the rats posed a potential pest problem. Failure to control pests in bird enclosures may
cause stress, disease transmission, and potential injury to the birds in the enclosure. A safe and effective program for the
control avian and mammalian pests must be established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the
birds and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas. Pest control methods and agents that may be harmful to birds
must not be applied in primary enclosures or other bird contact surfaces unless consistent with manufacturer
recommendations and does not cause harm to the birds.
To be corrected by July 10, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility personnel.
Additional Inspectors:
KATHARINE FRANK, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.75(c)(2) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Areas of peeling and chipped paint were observed in two of the nonhuman primate enclosures. In room 3 of the Lemur 
holding enclosures, the majority of the back wall of the enclosure had multiple areas of chipped paint resulting in exposure 
of the porous concrete wall surface. In the Tree Top Guenon holding enclosure, multiple areas of peeling paint were 
observed on the lower portion of the walls and on the floor exposing old paint and floor surfaces. Failure to maintain 
surfaces of housing facilities hinders the ability to adequately clean and sanitize and may affect the health and well-being 
of the animals. All surfaces must be maintained on a regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities that cannot be readily 
cleaned and sanitized must be replaced when worn or soiled.  
 
To be corrected by July 10, 2024. 
3.153(a)(1)(ii)  Critical
   
Primary enclosures. 
On January 9, 2024, a 5-year-old male Maccoa duck was found deceased in the filtration skimmer of the pool in Vollum 
Aviary. Subsequently, on January 17, 2024, the remaining ~6.5-year-old Maccoa duck and an 11-year-old female Ruddy 
duck were found deceased in the skimmer of the pool in the same enclosure. Failure to provide structurally sound and 
well-maintained enclosures can allow for the entrapment of animals and lead to possible injury or death. Primary 
enclosures must be designed and constructed of suitable materials so that they are structurally sound. The primary 
enclosures must be kept in good repair and protect the birds from injury. 
 
Corrected prior to the inspection date, June 26, 2024. 
3.158(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
At the time of inspection, several large adult rats were observed scurrying about in the flamingo enclosure. Facility 
personnel indicated they knew the rats posed a potential pest problem. Failure to control pests in bird enclosures may 
cause stress, disease transmission, and potential injury to the birds in the enclosure. A safe and effective program for the 
control avian and mammalian pests must be established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the

birds and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas. Pest control methods and agents that may be harmful to birds 
must not be applied in primary enclosures or other bird contact surfaces unless consistent with manufacturer 
recommendations and does not cause harm to the birds. 
 
To be corrected by July 10, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility personnel. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KATHARINE FRANK, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
